The latest @TIV_Podcast covering $MELI was phenomenal. If you are interested in a deep dive on $MELI I highly recommend listening to it. @Shawn_OMalley_ and @MnkeDaniel did an excellent job discussing MercadoLibre's thesis.

I want to add some of my own insights as well ğŸ‘‡ 

The bearish narrative for MELI credit focuses on NIMAL compression. The recent trend downwards is intentional. They are growing the credit card book so fast (104% YoY) and this front-loads massive P&L pain because IFRS forces MELI to provision credit losses upfront upon issuance. However, management confirmed that cohorts typically reach break-even in ~24 months. The massive 2024/2025 cohorts will begin reaching profit maturity later this year. Once credit growth normalizes (it may continue growing very fast for the next year or two), the profitability from this J-curve will materialize rapidly.

2026 tax reform is another regulatory win for $MELI. The transition to dual VAT begins this year. Dual VAT forces real-time tax automated deduction at the moment of transaction, eliminating the float that grey-market sellers use to survive. While MELI's biggest competition struggle to enforce this across millions of fragmented, low-tech sellers, Mercado Libre leverages Mercado Pago to handle this natively. MELI will effectively turn a massive compliance burden into a seamless user experience that competitors cannot easily replicate. This adds significant friction to cross-border players and smaller local sellers, as the compliance tax creates large overhead for them.

MELI also has a time-to-market advantage since it ships 10,000+ deploys per day while legacy banks deploy ~monthly. As open finance and the digital Real roll out, the winner will be the fastest integrator. MELI will integrate new credit scoring models and Drex protocols faster than anyone else.

On the bear thesis about free shipping being too expensive the data is clear that volume deflates costs. The latest -8% QoQ drop in Brazil shows that the cost per order is declining (while service improves). By aggregating volume MELI drives the marginal cost of the next package towards zero. This strengthens the flywheel and we will likely see this trend continue.

As for ecom competition for Shopee to continue growing (fast) they need to move upmarket. They will need to continue building trust with counterfeit protection, increase credit limits and increase delivery speed. All three are MELI's strongest advantages, making this a brutal uphill battle. Just to be clear Shopee has already found a lot of success in Brazil especially reaching profitability last year. Will be interesting to see how the landscape evolves this year.
